This Boston event has brought on a number of comments on how little terrorism there has been in the US, compared to what we feared could have happened, especially since 9/11. But globally, there has been a free-for-all killing spree going on without pause, and our armed forces have been out there participating, inciting, and providing probably 2 trillion dollars worth of financing to the global level of violence.

Since 9/11 we have succeeded in moving the terror war battlefield overseas. There are innocent people killed every week, innocent neighborhoods invaded with bombs or drones or other means, somewhere in the world, and we cannot afford to believe that we are disconnected from all of that.

At some point, we need to confront the global issue. Political violence, terror, is happening all the time, at a very high intensity. We need to focus on reducing the violence, globally, in addition to keeping it out of our own neighborhood.

I agree completely. My father was a milkman with an 8th grade education. My mother was the "educated" one in my family. She graduated from a Catholic high school. I thought I came from a solid family background.

But there was a chasm between what I knew and what my college classmates from a higher economic status knew. I thought engineers were people who ran trains. I thought majoring in business meant learning to type and do bookkeeping. I was an intelligent kid who read widely, but the only professionals I knew were public school teachers and later professors.

I simply had no idea of what those from wealthier families knew, did, and expected. And the situation has only gotten worse in the 40 years since I attended college.

I agree with this. Role models are everything. I come from a solid middle class background and have a pretty good university background. Now I work in a global field and have a lot of contact with politicians, decision makers and enterpreneurs and boy, can I see the different paths they took.

They all speak at least one other language, as a minimum. They spend money differently - appearance is important and nobody shows up being rumpled or with a hair out of place. They all went Ivy League or Oxbridge. Their parents never sold them the middle class line about "just follow your passion and see where it takes you" and "I just want you to be happy". No doubt their parents did want them to be happy, but slacking off in school was absolutely not an option. Right from the start, they were expected to become people of substance, like the people they saw around them... and they did.
Class of origin matters; pretend it does not at your peril.

Middle to lower income people have less opportunity to be in positive, balanced-power contact with doctors, lawyers, judges, accountants, engineers, and others whose work and its demands require higher education, skill, emotional self-regulation, and social conformity/collegiality.

I can speak as one who, despite high achievement in my lower middle class public schools and a heavy diet of public television, never even knew what a lawyer did, what a doctor did, what an accountant did, or what they earned or their style of life, until well after leaving high school. When I did get further education, as a legal assistant, my experiences working in a small law office have been deeply revealing, and confirm that there is a vast chasm of access for the differing layers of American society. My bosses are a married, upper-middle-class Catholic couple who have carefully raised their four children and ensured that all four have had the benefits of upper-middle class social association and good education. Every day I witness haves and have-nots, clued-in or clueless, through my work, and the depth of the chasm of life experience between the varying classes. I also witness the callousness of my upper middle class employers.

I've discovered, through the writings of Dr. Ruby Payne, a clear articulation of the costs of upward mobility which I can't recommend enough--totally my experience and the experience of many others I have known.

There is no "broad diagnosis" but a fact that these people were granted asylum from a Chechen conflict that they never were near (the family having been expelled from Chechnya in 1943). Moreover, the family Tsarnaev had no qualms about returning to their former homes - the place the fled to Asylum in America - the minute Moma was arrested for shoplifting. Meanwhile there are plenty of deserving people in real danger in such places as Africa, but they aren't white.

Understanding the Tsarnaev brothers is the booby prize; there are plenty of alienated immigrants who don't become radicalized and don't commit mass murder. I'd settle for understanding why people are allowed game the asylum system, why the FBI and CIA and Homeland Security can't find potential Jihadists even after they are pointed out to them? Even more urgent maybe to understand why the entire security system is thwarted when there is the inevitable variation is the phonetic spelling of a name in Cyrillic or Arabic? Are we such provincial boobs that our computers are useless in the face of foreign languages?

I don't think we will ever really know why this bombing happened.  Or why a mom buys her son guns that end up killing her and so many innocent children.  Or why a guy dresses up and goes to a Batman movie and opens fire.  The list goes on and on.    The media will dissect this a hundred ways.  But I do not think there will be a satisfying resolution.  Sociopaths exist in all societies.  They are on missions to destroy our feelings of safety and contentment.  Their hate and sense of entitlement astound all of us every time they unleash an act of violence and terror.  I don't think we will ever fully understand it. All we can do is stay vigilant and help those who have been affected by these crimes and to let our leaders know that we depend on them to keep us safe by working together to pass legislation that makes sense.  How many more funerals do they need to attend before they get it?
I'll just summarize a comment I made elsewhere: There is research that suggests that IQ is not inherited.

It has little to do with IQ, and more to do with behavior and expectations. I was suprised to meet very few brilliant and inpired intellectuals at university, but instead I met the children of professionals who expected their children to do well; not surprisingly, many mated and had kids. The belief that poorer, working class people are somehow inferior rubs off on their kids, and even if they make it to the university, the problem of money and self image is never completely erased...

One of the things that Freakonomics touched on is how children from parents who were of average IQ fared when they were adopted by parents with high IQ and high income. Their IQ did not change but, on average, they did better than their cohorts that were not adopted. The studies are quite suggestive!

I don't see any mention here of the parents' IQs. Isn't it likely that as women entered the professions both women and men increasingly sought mates of equal intelligence, resulting in segregation of couples by intelligence, with both higher incomes and smarter children accruing to those couples made up of 2 above average individuals?

True enough the U.S. isn't responsible for everything that adversely affects the world's Muslim community (not a peep from the Ulema about the murderous anti-Islamic rioting in Burma for example).  Still, it isn't exactly that Muslims in general and Arabs in particular have no reason to hold our country in contempt.  From our unbalanced and undiminished support for Israel even in the face of its continuing arrogation of the West Bank to our willingness to patronize the repressive sheiks of Araby for the sake of their petroleum reserves we haven't exactly been going out of our way to endear ourselves to these people.  Whether we like it or not, the Middle East and Southwest Asia belong to the people who live there.  And whether their hatred of the U.S. is or isn't justified we could make it a whole lot easier on ourselves by bidding that part of the world a heartfelt "Salaam."  As soon as we've done that the Chechens can go back to hating Moscow, the Uighurs can direct their full fury at Beijing, the Palestinians can concentrate on Tel Aviv and the Sunnis and Shiites can fight it out over who has the more righteous claim to the Prophet's legacy. At this point the only person benefiting from this country's unending involvement in the Middle East is Kim Jung-On.

It's economics. Single mothers partner with the state for child benefits rather than marry forfeiting food, housing and medical allowance. Prior to state benefits the economic partnership of a marriage was a necessity.

For women of means with or without children, marriage is a threat to their power, that is, their economic independence.

You see, it is economics.

So why marry? Because we experience our greatest personal growth through the trials of monogomy, as well as our most fulfilling sense of love, belonging, safety and sharing . Now who wouldn't want that?

You should read some nineteenth century novels and autobiographies to find out how confining and unfulfilling life-long monogamy used to be for both men and women. There was an intellectual and emotional revolt against marriage in the early 20th century and the sexual revolution was only a minor sequel to this process. I find the idea that marriage is necessary for a full life ridiculous. It may have benefits for child rearing but after all, we live much longer now and couples can easily separate after the children have left home.
